introduction: Noon Sakinah is the letter Noon (ن) with a sukoon (نْ). Tanween is the double vowel marks (ـًـ ـٍـ ـٌـ) at the end of nouns, producing the same 'n' sound. Both follow the same four rules depending on the letter that comes after them.

rules.description: When Noon Sakinah or Tanween is followed by one of six throat letters, pronounce the Noon/Tanween clearly without any nasalization (ghunnah) or merging.
rules.arabic_definition: إظهار النون الساكنة والتنوين عند حروف الحلق
rules.mnemonic_ar: هَمْزٌ هَاءٌ عَيْنٌ حَاءٌ غَيْنٌ خَاءٌ
rules.mnemonic_en: All six are throat letters (Huroof Halqiyyah) — they come from the deepest part of the throat to the opening.

examples.rule_applied: Izhar — Noon Sakinah followed by Hamzah (ء)
Izhar — Noon Sakinah followed by Haa (هـ) within one word

common_mistakes: Adding ghunnah (nasalization) — Izhar must be completely clear
Merging the Noon sound into the following letter
Not distinguishing between ح (Haa) and هـ (Haa) — both trigger Izhar but have different makhraj

rules.description: When Noon Sakinah or Tanween is followed by one of six letters (يرملون), the Noon/Tanween merges into the following letter. This ONLY occurs between two separate words, not within a single word.
rules.arabic_definition: إدخال النون الساكنة أو التنوين في الحرف الذي بعده

subtypes.mnemonic_en: Letters of Idgham with Ghunnah: يَنْمُو (yanmoo — 'it grows')
subtypes.description: The Noon Sakinah/Tanween merges into the following letter WITH a 2-beat nasal sound (ghunnah).

examples.rule_applied: Idgham with Ghunnah — Noon Sakinah followed by Yaa (ي)
Idgham with Ghunnah — Noon Sakinah followed by Waw (و)

subtypes.description: The Noon Sakinah/Tanween merges COMPLETELY into the following letter with NO nasal sound. The merge is total.

examples.rule_applied: Idgham without Ghunnah — Noon Sakinah followed by Raa (ر)
Idgham without Ghunnah — Noon Sakinah followed by Laam (ل)

rules.mnemonic_en: All six Idgham letters are collected in the word يَرْمَلُون (yarmaloon).
rules.critical_condition: Idgham ONLY occurs when the Noon Sakinah/Tanween and the Idgham letter are in TWO SEPARATE WORDS. If they are within one word, the rule is Izhar Mutlaq (absolute clarity). There are only four such words in the entire Quran: دُنْيَا، بُنْيَان، صِنْوَان، قِنْوَان.
common_mistakes: Applying Idgham within a single word (e.g., reading دُنْيَا with Idgham — this is WRONG)
Adding ghunnah with Laam and Raa — these two are WITHOUT ghunnah
Not merging completely — the Noon sound must disappear entirely

rules.description: When Noon Sakinah or Tanween is followed by the letter Baa (ب), the Noon/Tanween sound is converted into a hidden Meem (م) sound, pronounced with ghunnah for 2 beats.
rules.arabic_definition: قلب النون الساكنة أو التنوين ميمًا مخفاة عند الباء
rules.description_detailed: Only ONE letter triggers Iqlab: Baa (ب). The sound of Noon changes to a light Meem, and you pronounce the Meem with ghunnah (nasalization) for 2 beats before saying the Baa. In many Mushafs, a small Meem (مۢ) is written above the Noon to indicate this rule.

examples.rule_applied: Iqlab — Noon Sakinah followed by Baa (ب), Noon becomes Meem
Iqlab — Noon Sakinah followed by Baa (ب) within one word

common_mistakes: Pronouncing a full, clear Meem instead of a hidden Meem
Pressing the lips fully together — the lips should only come close, not fully shut
Forgetting the ghunnah — must hold for 2 beats

rules.description: When Noon Sakinah or Tanween is followed by any of 15 remaining letters, the Noon/Tanween is 'hidden' — pronounced with a light nasal sound (ghunnah) for 2 beats. The tongue prepares for the position of the following letter.
rules.arabic_definition: النطق بالنون الساكنة أو التنوين بصفة بين الإظهار والإدغام مع بقاء الغنة
rules.description_detailed: Ikhfaa is the most common rule in the Quran. The quality of the ghunnah (nasal sound) varies — it takes on a heavier or lighter quality depending on whether the following letter is heavy (mufakhham) or light (muraqqaq). For example, Ikhfaa before ط (heavy letter) has a heavier ghunnah than Ikhfaa before ت (light letter).

examples.rule_applied: Ikhfaa — Noon Sakinah followed by Qaaf (ق)
Ikhfaa — Noon Sakinah followed by Taa (ت) within one word
Ikhfaa — Noon Sakinah followed by Saad (ص) within one word
Ikhfaa — Noon Sakinah followed by Dhaa (ظ)

common_mistakes: Pronouncing the Noon too clearly (like Izhar) — it must be hidden
Merging completely (like Idgham) — the Noon sound should still be faintly present
Not adjusting the ghunnah quality for heavy vs. light following letters
Tongue touching the articulation point of the Noon — it should hover near the following letter's position

summary_table.description: Quick reference: What comes after Noon Sakinah/Tanween determines the rule
summary_table.izhar_letters: ء هـ ع ح غ خ
summary_table.ikhfaa_letters: ت ث ج د ذ ز س ش ص ض ط ظ ف ق ك
